list.item:
Mrs Thatcher, the Iron Lady, was in charge most of the time. So, still not a great time to be in England...
In 1982, we went to war with Argentina, over the Falklands. We won, for a change.
The Miners' strike of 1984 turned into a confrontation between government and unions; the government won.
In Ireland, the "Troubles" continued, with bombings, assassinations, and hunger strikes ...
The Thatcher government continued to shrink the state and privatise everything in sight

It wasn't all bad
The Rubik's Cube first appeared, as did Pac-Man, Super Mario, and Donkey Kong
IT spread out of the workplace into the home with a rash of "personal computers" : the IBM PC (1981); the Macintosh (1984); the Commodore 64 ; the BBC micro; the Amiga...
MTV was launched in the UK; also The Simpsons.
In 1981, Prince Charles and Lady Diana were married and everyone had a day off to watch
The World Wide Web was (allegedly) invented in 1989
The Berlin Wall fell and the Cold War started to thaw, kind of
We were property owners and I had a good job with proper pension rights!
At this date, mortgage debt was also popular.

We lived in Plantation Road long enough, and my credit was good enough, for us to undertake various home improvements, like installing central heating (on George's recommendation), enlarging the kitchen, and adding a balcony at the back.
This is the back of the house at the start of the update process in June 1980
When works were completed, we gave a very good party for the builders, a local outfit led by Andy Wrigley.

figure.head: Pam is the only one still cheerful by the time we got to the Gare du Nord

list.item: In August 1980, we took Pam with us on what should have been a simple expedition to Cherbourg by boat and train.

Striking French fishermen complicated things by blockading the channel ports, so we travelled via Dover and Zeebrugge, Calais, and Paris instead, taking two days and nights, and making considerable use of my Flexible Friend.
(Remember that this was all in a distant age before the channel tunnel, before Eurostar, before cashpoints, before the euro)
But when we eventually got to our seaside bungalow near Barneville, the beaches, sunshine, sand dunes, French food were all just wonderful.

div.head: A veddink
div.p: Also wonderful, in its own way, was Grandma's wedding for which the girls got new pink dresses and lots of elderly relatives appeared. It was catered by a rather nice hotel in Windsor, and was my first encounter with beef wellington.
After a few years, we decided we had outgrown the house and were ready to move on. In April, Belinda and Sarah were given the opportunity to redecorate our bedroom wall :

In unrelated news, not content with innumerable swimming certificates and such like, Belinda started learning to play the violin.
Sounding quite good, by September

div.head: Swanage
div.p: The same year, in August, we went on a proper family seaside holiday

div.head: Financial wizardry
div.p: In 1982, we sold Plantation Road for £24,000. But moving on still required a new mortgage: I made it big enough to finance a holiday trip to Malawi as well. So we spent Christmas 1982 visiting friends and family in Limbe, Blantyre, and Zomba again.

list.item: Fresh new mortgage in hand we moved decisively up the property ladder and into proper North Oxford, or Walton Manor at least.

Our new address, 110 Southmoor Rd, was a magnificent four storey victorian mansion, a snip at £53,000. It had been minimally improved by the vendors, but was in need of constant repair, which (in due course) we gave it.
We moved in on 25 March 1983, and stayed there (eventually) for the next 30 years.

figure.head: 110 is the slightly grubbier one on the left.
In October 1983, the Woodcraft Folk (West Oxford Branch) went to London to do their bit for CND.
Grandma gave us this hand-made depiction of Burnard Towers to celebrate our fifth year there/
In July 1985, we went for a bracing Cornish holiday, taking in St Michael's Mount. It didn't rain ALL the time, but Lilette vowed she would never visit the English seaside again.

list.item: Inter alia, there were school fetes and the Little Clarendon St Fair and the Jericho Festival..
In June 1986, there was a special street party to celebrate our street's hundredth birthday (or thereabouts).

I concocted and distributed a register of the inhabitants from old street directories. Belinda played in a scratch orchestra. There was tea and cake, and face painting, and bagpipes. Very North Oxford.

figure.head: Colin Matthew piped in the event

list.item: Belinda starred as Tevye in Cherwell School's 1987 production of Fiddler on the Roof (little knowing ...)
Sarah and the rest of the Oxford Girls Choir took Dido on tour in France in August
Lilette celebrated her birthday at an OU summer school in Scotland
In September I took up a month-long fellowship in Gottingen at the Max Planck Institute for Historical Research (sounds better in German)
And then...

div.p: (I'll give my lecture on the global significance of the TEI another day)

div.p: Possibly the first time I'd been unavoidably absent for Belinda's birthday. But not the last.

div.head: In 1988, Pam and Mike got married at Wolfson College

figure.head: The 80s were also famous for costume drama

div.head: But we finished the decade by taking another tropical Xmas holiday
div.p: This time, we all went to Mauritius to visit grandmère in Curepipe, with side trips to Villa Caroline to see in new year, to Port Louis and its Grapefruit Gardens, to various Mauritian parties ...
